name: U.S. Records

choices.name: Use the Record Selection Table for planning U.S. research.

hidden.content:
• This tool helps you determine which records to search first and which to search afterwards, for each category of information.
    For example, if you were looking for a U.S. ancestor's birthplace, you would start with vital records, church records, and census records; then you would try newspapers and obituaries.

• * Good: Make a list of two or more helpful record types to search, for at least two ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for at least four ancestors.

content.text:
1. Study the FamilySearch ☆U.S. Record Selection Table, also known as the Record Finder.
  2. Using the information in the table, map out a strategy for records to search for your U.S. ancestors.

• * Good: Using the articles and videos in this Choice, write down key learnings about records for two or more of the following topics: Public Records Index, Ancestry Wiki, unusual record sources, pre-1850 records, image-only collections. Then use the learnings for record searches for your U.S. ancestors.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for four or more topics.

content.text:
1. Public Records Index: Learn about the United States Public Records Index. This collection has records for many people who lived in the United States from 1970-2009, which can be a great help for those tracing your recent ancestors or missing family members.

    ☆ FS - U.S. Public Records Index
    QUIZ

  2. Explore the U.S. Public Records Index collection on FamilySearch to find information and clues about recent ancestors.
  3. Ancestry Wiki: Watch this video to help you explore the Ancestry Wiki, which points to many types of records.

    ☆ AC—What Records Exist—28:29   
    • Learning Center, Ancestry Wiki
    • Card catalog




  4. Alternatives: Learn how to find valuable information from unusual record sources.

    ☆ RT—Finding Valuable Information from Unusual Records - 2017
    ☆ AC: Ten Places You Didn't Think to Look - 2015

  5. Pre-1850: Learn how to find U.S. records before 1850.

    ☆ FS—U.S. Records Before 1850—57:06 - 2016

  6. Index-only: Recognize index-only records (no record image included), why they are created, and how to use them in your research.

    ☆ AC—Index-Only Records—30:38 - 2015  
    • Intro
    • Record vs. index
    • Is a copy needed?
    • How do I get a copy?
    • Conclusion



    ☆ LT—Hidden in Plain Sight: A Guide to Image-Only Record Collections

name: Location
section_name: Learn about location and geography as search tools.Vault
summary: Becoming familiar with locations and geographies will help you determine where your ancestors lived and where they moved to, or from.

choices.name: Devise a strategy for locating your ancestors, based on where they lived.

hidden.content:
• Understand geographical borders over time, to learn what types of records might be available.
  • Learn where your ancestors previously lived, and where to look if counties or towns are missing for an ancestor.
  • Discover how tying events and jurisdictions together can lead to the right record sources.
  • Look for records before looking for names.
  • Examine records carefully for additional clues.

name: Regions and States

summary: In addition to searching for ancestors by U.S. state, you can find a wealth of state resources that give you additional information about your ancestors and the states they lived in.

choices.name: Do effective research in individual U.S. states.

hidden.content:
• * Good: Using the articles and videos in this Choice, write down key learnings for all of the following topics: About state research, research techniques for U.S. states, resources for U.S. state research. Then use the learnings for record searches for U.S. ancestors in a chosen state.
  • * Proficient: Same as above, for two or more states.

content.text:
1. In the State list (just below the Statue of Liberty picture above), access the State page you are interested in. Each State page has Goals and Choices, similar to other Projects in The Family History Guide.
  2. In each State page, you can access a county of interest in the County list at the top (such as AL Counties).
  3. Resources: Read this article for an overview on doing state-by-state research.

    ☆ AR—Using State Resources for Genealogy - 2011

  4. Learn about techniques for doing research in any U.S. state.

    ☆ GC—Steps For Genealogy Research In Any State

  5. Find free resources for research in all 50 states.

    ☆ FHD—Free Genealogy Research Sites for Every Single U.S. State

  6. Explore the ☆U.S. Genealogy Records links on the LDSGenealogy.com site (non-denominational).

choices.name: Explore the RootsMapper website to visually trace the immigration paths of your ancestors.

content.text:
1. Go to www.rootsmapper.com.
  2. Click the blue login button.
  3. Sign in to FamilySearch so RootsMapper can use your Family Tree information.
  4. Click Start and select the number of generations to display (default is 3). Ancestors appear as colored dots, with the number inside matching the number of generations before you.
  5. Drag the map and follow the colored lines to see migration paths. Zoom in (+) to add space between ancestors.
  6. Click an ancestor dot to move it away from nearby dots, or show the direct path from the ancestor to you, or display info about the ancestor. You can also change map options and pedigree view, or see country statistics.
  7. See more information on using RootsMapper.

    ☆ Official RootsMapper Demo - 2014
